metadata.case_name: Dhanrajamal Gobindram v. Shamji Kalidas Co.

facts.text: On October 24, 1957, Messrs. Dhanrajamal Gobindram (buyers) entered into an agreement with Messrs. Shamji Kalidas Co. (sellers) for purchase of 500 bales of African raw cotton (ARBP 52 F.A.Q. Crop/58) at Rs. 1,401 nett per candy CIF Bombay, shipment February/March 1958, subject to Bye-laws of East India Cotton Association Ltd., Bombay (except bye-law 35), Force Majeure Clause, and specific clauses on import licence, carry over, resale.

Agreement stamped as letter No. SK Bom/13/2014 confirmed by buyers, includes clause 6 requiring buyers to obtain import licence by February 20, 1958, and communicate number to sellers; failure entitles sellers to carry over or demand payment and delivery in British East Africa, or resell at risk and account of buyers.
By letter dated November 30, 1957, contract amended: sellers confirm carry over for two months (March and April 1958) if necessary, buyers to pay carry over charges at Mombasa rate.
Contract not performed. Sellers wrote five letters between March 1, 1958, and May 26, 1958; carried forward contract, invoked resale after notice, claimed Rs. 34,103.15 via debit note.
Buyers replied on June 3, 1958, stating contract void and/or illegal, no obligation to perform, no right of sale on their account, alleged sale not binding.
Sellers invoked arbitration clause and Bye-law 38-A, filed petition under s.20 Indian Arbitration Act in Bombay High Court Original Side.
Buyers' first affidavit July 31, 1958: cls.6 and 7 unlawful, contravene import policy and Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947; contract invalid, arbitration clause not binding.
Buyers' second affidavit February 4, 1959: 'subject to usual Force Majeure Clause' vague, no consensus ad idem, contract void ab initio.
Buyers' third affidavit February 27, 1959: November 30, 1957 letter void for contravention of Import Trade Control Act and FERA, 'if necessary' vague.
K.T. Desai J. dismissed petition March 3, 1959: dispute on legality/validity to be under ss.32/33, not s.20.
Sellers' appeal: Chainani CJ and S.T. Desai J. remanded April 28, 1959, directing decision on validity before reference.
Buyers' fourth affidavit November 16, 1959: Bye-law 38-A statutory under Forward Contracts Regulation Act 1952, s.46 Arbitration Act applies, s.20 inapplicable due to inconsistent machinery.
K.T. Desai J. November 26-27, 1959: petition not maintainable, no s.20(4) action possible due to Bye-law 38-A; but contract not void for FERA/Import Act/vagueness.

Divisional Bench (Tarkunde and Chitale JJ.): allowed sellers' appeal, dismissed buyers' cross-objections, petition maintainable, order filing agreement and reference per Bye-law 38-A, costs to sellers.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate from Bombay High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the contract is void for illegality under Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947 (s.5), Import Trade Control Act 1947, or related policies due to clauses 6 and 7.
Whether the contract is void for vagueness/uncertainty due to 'subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause' and 'if necessary' in amendment letter.
Whether petition under s.20 Arbitration Act is maintainable given statutory Bye-law 38-A of East India Cotton Association Ltd. and ss.46/47 Arbitration Act.
Whether governing law is Indian law or law of British East Africa (lex loci solutionis).

petitioner_arguments.text: Clauses 6 and 7 contravene s.5 FERA by envisaging payments/acquisition of property/foreign exchange in Africa without Reserve Bank exemption; also breach Import policy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947 s.5; Import and Export Control Act 1947 ss.3,4A; Import Trade Control Order

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Subject to usual Force Majeure Clause' vague, no consensus ad idem as multiple possible clauses.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Contract Act s.29; precedents like British Industries v. Patley Pressings; Scammell v. Ouston

petitioner_arguments.text: 'If necessary' in November 30 letter vague, no consensus.
S.20 inapplicable as Bye-law 38-A provides inconsistent machinery (Chairman appoints arbitrators), ousting court powers under s.20(4); statutory under Forward Contracts Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arbitration Act ss.20,46,47; Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act 1952; Ghulam Jilani v. Muhammad Hassan

petitioner_arguments.text: Governing law is lex loci solutionis (British East Africa) due to performance there.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Pollock & Mulla Contract Act; Dicey Conflict of Laws

respondent_arguments.text: Contract saved by FERA s.21(2),(3): implied term requiring permission, legal proceedings allowed subject to Reserve Bank permission.
Resale under cl.6 by sellers for own account, not agents; no FERA breach per Sale of Goods Act.
'Usual Force Majeure Clause' capable of being made certain by evidence of trade usage; not vague.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Contract Act s.29; Lebeaupin v. Crispin; Shamrock S.S. Co. v. Storey

respondent_arguments.text: 'If necessary' means if buyers fail to provide licence number, extending discretion under cl.6.
S.20 maintainable: court files agreement, refers per Bye-laws; Arbitration Act applies where consistent (ss.46,47); ministerial act possible.

court_reasoning.text: Contract not void for FERA illegality: s.21(2) engrafts implied term requiring Reserve Bank permission; s.21(3) allows proceedings subject to permission; 'permission' covers s.5 prohibitions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: FERA prevents using Act as shield against performance.

court_reasoning.text: Resale with notice by seller for own account, buyer liable for deficit, no profit to buyer, no FERA breach.
'Usual Force Majeure Clause' not vague: 'usual' refers to specific trade clause, capable of proof; distinguishes cases without 'usual'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Commercial documents construed broadly to avoid invalidity.

court_reasoning.text: 'If necessary' not vague: modifies cl.6 discretion, extends to March/April if buyers fail on licence.
S.20 applicable: court decides validity/existence (saved power), files agreement, performs ministerial reference to Chairman per Bye-laws; ss.46/47 allow inconsistencies to prevail.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not completely ousted; Bye-law 38-A covers appointment.

court_reasoning.text: Dispute under s.20 arises 'out of or in relation to' contract per Bye-law 38-A, even on existence.
Indian law governs: parties chose Bombay High Court jurisdiction and Indian arbitration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Qui elicit judicem eligit jus'; arbitration in India.

holdings.text: Contract not void for illegality under FERA or Import Acts.
Contract not void for vagueness re Force Majeure or 'if necessary'.
Petition under s.20 maintainable despite Bye-law 38-A.

precedents_cited.relevance: Expounds meaning of force majeure as wider than vis major, including strikes, machinery breakdown.
Held 'subject to force majeure conditions' vague due to variety of clauses; distinguished by 'usual'.
'On hire purchase terms' vague; distinguished by 'usual' allowing evidence.
'Usual colliery guarantee' in charter-party valid as common usage.
Courts strive to give meaning to commercial documents.

precedents_cited.case_name: Adamastos Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Construe commercial agreements broadly, not astute to find defects.
Categories of arbitrations; this is statutory with court supervision limited.
Dispute on existence still 'arising out of or in relation to' contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: N.V. Kwik Hoo Tong v. James Finlay & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Choice of forum implies choice of its law.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition to file agreement and refer; applies subject to inconsistencies with statutory bye-laws.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: No illegality; s.21 saves contracts with implied permission term, allows proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Import and Export (Control) Act 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Cl.7 partly contravenes under circumstances but not wholly void.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Agreements capable of being made certain not void.

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Seller resells for own account with notice, buyer liable for deficit.

statutes_cited.name: Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Bye-laws of East India Cotton Association statutory.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected all contentions of appellants (buyers), upheld Divisional Bench order allowing petition under s.20, directing filing of agreement and reference to arbitration per Bye-law 38-A.
outcome.relief_granted: Petition under s.20 maintainable; dispute referred to arbitration.

key_quotes.text: The effect of these provisions is to prevent the very thing which is claimed here, namely, that the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act arms persons against performance of their contracts by setting up the shield of illegality.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects illegality defence under FERA s.21.

key_quotes.text: The use of the word 'usual' makes all the difference, and the meaning of the condition may be made certain by evidence about a force majeure clause, which was in contemplation of parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds 'usual Force Majeure Clause' as not vague.

key_quotes.text: So long as something is saved, it cannot be said that the Court after receiving the agreement and ordering that it be filed, becomes completely functus officio.
key_quotes.speaker: court
